Situation1: They share only one open evening before a busy travel week.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: Several other volunteers can easily cover the first part of the shift if someone shows up a little late.
Story: I glanced at my phone, rereading the text from my boyfriend: “Can’t wait for our night together. Feels like forever since we had time, just us.” He was right. With both our schedules packed, tonight was the only open evening before I left for a week-long work trip. I wanted to make it special, to show him he mattered. But then my calendar pinged—a reminder for my volunteer shift at the shelter. I was supposed to be there at seven, sharp. The coordinator always emphasized punctuality, even though I knew a few others could cover the first hour if I was late. Still, I’d promised to be reliable, and the animals counted on us. My chest tightened as I pictured my boyfriend waiting at the restaurant, checking his watch, while I rushed through traffic, torn between two promises. I wanted to be the dependable volunteer and the loving girlfriend, but tonight, I couldn’t be both.
